message.content:
cs.DC, cs.DS, cs.NI, cs.LG, cs.SY

Reasoning: 
1. cs.DC (Distributed, Parallel, and Cluster Computing) - The paper discusses distributed algorithms on natural graphs, which are known to be difficult to partition, and proposes an efficient and scalable Allreduce primitive for power-law data. This suggests that the paper belongs to the cs.DC sub-category.
2. cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) - The paper deals with large datasets that exhibit power-law statistics and proposes a new approach for Sparse Allreduce. This suggests that the paper belongs to the cs.DS sub-category.
3. cs.NI (Networking and Internet Architecture) - The paper discusses communication-intensive algorithms on natural graphs and proposes a new approach for Allreduce that improves on existing butterfly and round-robin networks. This suggests that the paper belongs to the cs.NI sub-category.
4. cs.LG (Machine Learning) - The paper mentions that many machine learning algorithms, including regression, factor (topic) models, and clustering, involve an Allreduce operation. This suggests that the paper belongs to the cs.LG sub-category.
5. cs.SY (Systems and Control) - The paper proposes a replication scheme to deal with node failures, which is a common problem in distributed systems. This suggests that the paper belongs to the cs.SY sub-category.
